answerText: There is an injection that takes care of internal and external parasites. There are chemicals you can apply on their body or spray/dip the cow. You will need to consult with your vet for advise/direction

choiceText: At what age do I dehorn my cow?
answerText: Cows can be dehorned at 4 days of age particularly to avoid much bleeding. It is usually done using caustic soda. In the case of traumatic injury it can be done by a vet at any age

choiceText: Do I need to keep record as its done in poultry?
answerText: Yes. Its necessary to keep record as this will help you with information which of the cow to select for breeding based on previous performance record. It helps you know the age of the animal (which will be useful for vaccination, weaning and marketing). It will help you know when to breed, remove those not producing well etc.

choiceText: How do I restrain my cow to carry out treatment, hoof trimming etc?
answerText: Usually the person managing may know how to restrain them. You will however need a crush on the farm to keep animals securely when you want to treat, spray etc.

choiceText: Diseases
How do I know that my animal/s is/are sick?
answerText: When you notice the following; your animal refuses to eat, abnormal movement, lying down, watery stool, blood in urine and feces, vomiting, jaundice, emaciation, not growing properly and many abnormal signs.

choiceText: My cow brings out too much saliva from the mouth
answerText: Your animal may have bad teeth, fever, wounds in the mouth, something might be choking it, presence of foreign body in the month. Grab the tongue, check for sores/wounds or if something is stock in the throat. Rinse the mouth with disinfectant if it’s a sore. Administer antibiotic injection preferably Penstrep. Also give the animal some soft feed.

choiceText: I have observed some occasion where too much gas collects in my cows stomach (bloating) leading to death.
answerText: It might have eaten bad food, may be due to sudden change in diet, or have eaten poison.

choiceText: Sometimes my animal passes hard stool.
answerText: It may be due to eating food without enough water or not eating enough roughage (Constipation)

choiceText: My animal has gone for more than two days without passing stool; what is the cause?
answerText: If the animal has been eating, check if it has eaten dry food without water. Give enough fresh water for animal to drink, give fresh green grass or other roughages cooking oil, mineral oil 1-4 litres of oil, Magnesium sulphate (MgSO4).

choiceText: My cow has stopped eating its cud and is not eating properly.
answerText: This means that the cow has no good digestion. It may be due to feeding too many antibiotics. The cow may be having constipation. It may be due to “hardware disease” caused by ingestion of sharp object if you see that the animal is in pain and grunt. Use antibiotics, provide fresh green grass and give VitB inj. If there is no improvements consult your veterinary doctor for further examination.

choiceText: Sometimes I see one or two animals not eating, will be restless, rolling, kicking the belly, sweating, unable to pass stool and sitting like a dog.
answerText: The animal may be in pain called colic. Give pain killers like aspirin, paracetamol or Novalgin. Give some oil or MgSO4 (Consult your vet if the condition persists)

choiceText: Animal passing loose/watery stool for more than 3 days.
answerText: The animal may have parasites in the stomach, have eaten bad food or water, or contacted viruses or bacteria. There may have been a sudden change in diet or have eaten poison or dangerous plants. Give a lot of water, give parasitic drugs and give antibiotics. If the animal looks sick and has fever, the diarrhea is probably caused by bacteria or viruses. Call a veterinary doctor.

choiceText: Stool is red or black in color but no diarrhoea.
answerText: There may be bleeding into the digestive tract. This may also be due to poison. If the animal is not sick and no fever the diarrhea may be due to a change in feed or too much rich feed. Give plenty water, give small amounts of fluid frequently until the animal starts to urinate normally. Give kaolin and antibiotics (sulphadimidine) Consult your vet if the condition persists.

choiceText: I have noticed coughing and difficulty in breathing in my herd of cattle with those affected unable eat, aving nasal discharges and lag behind (standing quiet)
answerText: Your cattle may be aving pneumonia (Contagious bovine pleura-pneumonia) caused by a bacteria.  It is spread in the droplets discharged from nose of infected cattle. Control of the disease is by vaccination and slaughter or quarantine of affected animal.  There is no available treatment for the disease

choiceText: What causes teat swelling and obstruction and sometimes udder becomes hard? How can I prevent or handle it?
answerText: It is usually caused by improper milking or bruises to the udder. Certain bacteria may contribute to the cuse of this condition Treatment with antibiotics must commenced early

choiceText: What may be the cause the appearance of hard/firm swelling (lumps) that in some cases are generalized with the animal unable to eat well and having discharge from the nose. The condition is also noticed in sheep and goats in the herd
answerText: This may be a viral disease that is transmitted by mosquitoes and other biting insects e.g stomoxys. There is vaccine for the control of the disease. Treatment is only to prevent secondary bacteria infection.

choiceText: What is the cause of excessive salivation and sometimes lameness with loss of body weight and reduced milk. More so affected pregnant cow usually abort
answerText: The cattle may be having Foot and mouth Disease. It is caused by a viral disease and has no treatment. Antibiotics can be used to prevent secondary bacterial infection. Wound dressing of Blisters/ulcers can be carried out.

choiceText: A particular condition has been reported in nearby farms where cattle die suddenly and blood oozes from anus, nose and mouth
answerText: Consult with your vet doctor. The treatment may be difficult; penicillin is indicated at early stage of the disease. Dead animals should not be opened rather tey should be burned. Vaccinate animals to prevent occurrence of the disease

choiceText: How do I handle a disease in cattle sowing nervous signs such as muscle twitching and the animal walking in circles and in some paddling their legs while lying
answerText: This may be an infection that is transmitted by ticks. It can be treated using antibiotics (tetracycline) and can be prevented by proper tick control

choiceText: My calf have been passing a watery feces; how can I handle it?
answerText: When you notice that withdraw milk from the calf and provide clean water three times a day; on the second day give half the normal ration of milk plus water and glucose; do that on the 3rd day also and return to normal milk ration on the fourth day

choiceText: What should I do when calving is overdue?
answerText: When calving is over due (by more than one week) call a veterinary doctor

choiceText: When should I call a veterinary doctor during calving?
answerText: Calving normally occurs without difficulty. However if there is a long delay between the breaking of the water in uterus and the first sight of part of the fetus or if the calving takes more than 3 hours after some part of the young is seen or if the calf is not coming out in a normal position call a veterinary doctor

choiceText: Marketing
Pigs
Housing
What precaution should I take in housing farrowing sow and the piglet
answerText: Bring the sow one week prior to farrowing to the farrowing pen where the sow can stay for 5-8weeks. The piglets are weaned by removing the sow. Confine the sow to a farrowing crate a few days before to a week after birth. The piglets can remain in the farrowing pen after weaning until about 12 weeks

choiceText: What type of housing is appropriate for rearing pigs?
answerText: Pigs require simple housing free from draught and the floor well drained or concreted. You can have a simple semi-covered pens constructed with blocks or timber. The walls must be provided with large openings to provide sufficient air in hot period. Several pens can be arranged in rows.  A fenced paddock where water and feed is provided can suffice. The ground should be well drained and sufficient distance from living/residential areas. It should have an east-west orientation

choiceText: Breeding
I got my pigs from the open pig market close to our community but I am thinking of replacing them with improved breeds from a modern farm. What are the problems I might face with the improved breed.
answerText: While improved breeds of pigs are usually faster growers, your local breeds are likely to be more disease resistant. It would be wiser for you to get cross breeds I.e. breeds that combine traits from both local and improved breeds.

choiceText: At what point can I mate my growing female pigs?
answerText: Growing female pigs are called gilts. Those coming on heat for their first time should not be served immediately. They are still too young and their bodies are not yet strong enough to carry and deliver a good litter.

choiceText: How do I know that my pregnant pig is ready to give birth?
answerText: In the last 14 days of pregnancy the udder will increase in size. It feels firmer, and the nipples stand out more towards the end of the pregnancy. When the pregnant pig eventually becomes very restless, it may be a sign that it would soon give birth. About a day before the birth of the first piglet, the udder will start to look much redder.

choiceText: What preparations do I need to make before the delivery?
answerText: At about the expected delivery date the sow should be put in a pen of her own, which should be disinfected first. It should be served adequate feed and water. Sufficient straw should be provided for her to make a nest for the piglets. It is more advisable to use green fodder to avoid any form of constipation.

choiceText: At what age does a sow reach sexual maturity and is ready for breeding?
answerText: 4-5months, but first service should be at 8 months when the weight is between 100 and 130kg

choiceText: How long will it take for a sow to come on heat after weaning
answerText: After weaning a sow can come on heat within 5-7 days and at 3weeks interval until successful mating/conception

choiceText: My sow has started breeding for almost 3 years now and wondering if I should sell her off?
answerText: A sow has a productive life of 4-5years. You may therefore still keep her 2 more years unless if you observe certain changes that has cause reduced productivity.

choiceText: How do I know that my sow is on heat?
answerText: You will observe general restlessness, vulva turns red and swollen, white mucous discharge. She will be willing to stand to be mounted by the male. After the heat she will not stand to be mounted

choiceText: How long does the heat period of pigs last?
answerText: The heat period of sows last for 5 days only. The real heat last for 40-60hours.

choiceText: My sow and the boar are in separate areas; should I take the male to the sow now that she is on heat?
answerText: Take the sow to the boar: this is less upsetting to sow. Put them together not before feeding. The boar should serve twice with an interval of 12hours.

choiceText: How do I know that my sow has conceived after mating?
answerText: If the sow did not conceive,  she will return on heat in about 3weeks time. So when she has not come on heat after 3 weeks it may suggest that she has conceived

choiceText: I mated my sow 2 months ago; how long does it take before my sow litter?
answerText: It usually takes 114 days that is 3months, 3 weeks, 3 days.

choiceText: What necessary preparation should I make before farrowing?
answerText: Farrowing pen should be dry and free of drought. Clean the farrowing pen roughly, and soap with strong disinfectant. Apply with wash mixed with Gamma BHCN similar insecticide to the pen with to control mange and lice at least 10 days before expected farrowing. Denorm the sow 2 weeks before the expected farrowing,

choiceText: What characteristics should I look for when selecting a gilt for breeding?
answerText: Look for a gilt that have not less tha 12 teats; this will allow for having enough teat for large litter. Select gilt from sows that wean 9-10 piglets per litter and known to be good mothers. The pigs should be fast growers, have strong legs with adequate body length, developed hams and comparatively light heads. The boar is important in determining the quality of the herd. The boar should come from a fertile mother and a father whose other offspring are satisfactory, have sound feet, good full hams, uniform curve of the back and a good length; it should have at least 12 teats.

choiceText: I bought a boar at 5 months and wants to know when I can start using it for mating?
answerText: It is advisable to wait until it is 8 months old. During the first two months of service it should mate only twice per week. Subsequently, the boar can serve at least 6 per week.

choiceText: How many boar do I need in my pig farm?
answerText: You will need a ratio of 1 boar to 15 sows

choiceText: Why do people want their pigs not to be too fat?
answerText: A fat sow will take longer time to come on heat. She is also more likely to crush her young piglets

choiceText: My sow is pregnant and due to deliver, as a starter how do I prepare for the arrival of my piglets?
answerText: Try and heat up a small area with inferred lamp or 50 Walt electric bulb hung 30-40 cm above the piglets. It keeps the going pigs warm, prevents pneumonia and crushing and they stay under the lamp when not feeding. Provide chipped straw or saw dust on the floor. Wash the sow with soap and water to remove dirt. Move the sow to the farrowing pen 4-7 days before expected day of farrowing to get her familiarized

choiceText: What should be the birth and weaning weight of piglets
answerText: Approximately 1.5kg birth weight and 16-18kg weaning weight

choiceText: How many piglets should be weaned per year for a sow
answerText: At least 18 piglets

choiceText: Feed and water
What precaution should I take when trying to change my pigs feed?
answerText: Change their feed gradually over a period of 1 week or more; sudden change in feedstuffs may upset and prevent pigs from gaining weight.

choiceText: Should I continue with the same feed I feed my sow with or I should change now that she is pregnant?
answerText: A week before service, give the sow/gilt 1kg of feed extra per day (standard is 2.5kg per day). Continue this for one week after service. During the last month of pregnancy give 0.5-1kg extra feed per day but decrease this gradually one week before farrowing and provide plenty of water to help prevent congested gut during farrowing.

choiceText: What proportion of protein to energy content should my pigs feed contain?
answerText: Preferably 10-20% of the feed should be protein. Fattening pigs will require least protein while nursing sows and piglets on sow require most.

choiceText: Can I include some minerals in my pigs feed?
answerText: You can add 0.5% each of bone meal, salt a vitamin and or calcium

choiceText: I have heard some farmers adding salts to their pigs feed; is it proper?
answerText: Minerals are very important; it is important that the ration should contain some calcium and common salt. .

choiceText: I want to go into piggery but not knowledgeable on what should constitute their feed
answerText: It is advisable to consult a professional. However, pig meal should contain both energy (e. g maize, wheat, rice barley, sorghum, oats, sweet potato, irish potato, cereals bran) and protein (cotton seed meals, soya bean meal foods, sesame-seed meal, blood meal, fish meal, peas, beans, groundnuts etc). In the case of both energy and protein foodstuffs, it is best to mix a number of different types and not to feed one type alone. About 10-20% of the mixture should be protein food. The mixture should include0.5% of each of the following; bone meal, salt, a vitamin mixture and calcium

choiceText: What the common vaccines available for pigs?
answerText: Young piglets from 10days should have a high protein feed available to them. This has to be fed in a small creep or areas where the mother cannot eat the feed.

choiceText: What proportion of energy and protein is needed for nursing sows?
answerText: Nursing sow require more of protein than energy source feed

choiceText: Vaccination
Why is my vet insisting that I administer iron injection to my piglets?
answerText: Piglets may develop a serious shortage of iron in the blood because the mother’s milk does not contain enough iron to cover the piglets. There is need to administer an iron injection to supplement.

choiceText: What the common vaccines available for pigs?
answerText: There are many vaccines but are not commonly available in  Nigeria

choiceText: Routine practices
My grower pigs are not growing as fast as I expect. What could be the problem and what should I do about it?
answerText: Confirm the growth performance of the parent stock. If the parents are fast growers then you have to feed them a balanced diet, sufficient water and ensure regular deworming. If the problem persists, contact your extension agent.

choiceText: My neighbor insists that if I raise my pigs on free range I might make higher profits. I am considering releasing my pigs to scavenge.
answerText: While scavenging might appear to save you some cost, thus increasing profit, you would be contributing to polluting the environment, exposing your pigs to diseases and also exposing them to the possibility of being stolen. Piglets from scavenging pigs also have a slower growth rate. It would be better to find cheaper ways of feeding them.

choiceText: I noticed that my pig is not comfortable with the piglets breastfeeding. The breast feels hard and looks reddish. What is the problem?
answerText: This might be caused by an infection of the breast, also called Mastitis. You need to administer an antibiotic (Penicillin or Streptomycin) You can get a vet to do that for you.

choiceText: At what age should I castrate my male piglets?
answerText: Castration is best carried out within the first 2 weeks of age.

choiceText: At what age do I castrate my male pig?
answerText: You can castrate between 14-21 days of age

choiceText: At what age do I give iron to my piglets
answerText: Iron helps in preventing piglet anemia. Iron dextran are given between one and seven days and repeated after a week. It is usually given to pigs raised on concrete floor.

choiceText: At what age do I clip my pigs teeth?
answerText: Teeth clipping (canine and premolar teeth) should be done as soon as they are given birth (within 24hrs). This is done to prevent injuries to mothers breast and other litter mates

choiceText: Diseases
I had a disease incidence that wiped out all my flock some time ago. What kind of disease could that be and what can I do to avoid a repeat?
answerText: You most likely had an incidence of African Swine Fever. There is no known vaccine or treatment for now. You can however take some steps to minimize the risk of a repeat. Make sure you have foot deeps at the entrances of your pens. Avoid visiting other farms. Be quick to contact a vet as soon as you notice symptoms of disease on your farm.

choiceText: I learned that I should bath my boar before mating but do not know why.
answerText: You can wash the boar with soap and water every 4 months and spray for lice and mange to prevent it from transferring disease to the sow during mating

choiceText: Marketing
What should be the marketing age of pigs
answerText: Marketing age is from 6 month. At that age the pig should be approximately weighing 100kg

choiceText: Dogs
Housing
Breeding
My bitch is 9 month old and I have started seeing signs of heat should I mate her?
answerText: Female dogs reach maturity between 10 and 12 month. However it is recommended that you do not mate her when she comes on heat the first time.

choiceText: I have mated my bitch for 3 consecutive times and she has not conceived.
answerText: The timing of the mating may be wrong. The bitch or the male may have fertility problem. Next time try a different male or change the timing of the mating. You can get a male dog to be in the house to solve the problem. Also take the dog for check-up

choiceText: Why is my bitch still discharging blood even though she was mated?
answerText: It is possible you mated the dog too early. You may need to take the bitch for examination by a veterinarian

choiceText: My dog has reached 61 days of pregnancy and there is no sign of delivery?
answerText: When a dog gets pregnant, it will take 60 days for it to deliver. Sometimes it may take up to 65 days. If she is still eating well and active, then there’s no problem. If she has stopped eating and is inactive for two days then consult your vet doctor.

choiceText: My bitch died a day after delivery, what should I do for the puppies to survive?
answerText: Keep them in a warm place. If there is a bitch that just delivered you can take them to her to get milk. You can use milk for babies and prepare with glucose for them.

choiceText: What makes bitches to suddenly lose weight after whelping?
answerText: A Bitch during breastfeeding (after delivery) needs much energy for herself and for the puppies. The bitch should therefore be fed four times her normal meal. If that is not done she would significantly reduce weight

choiceText: Feed and water
How many times should I feed my adult dog in a day?
answerText: Once the feed is balanced, an adult dog can get all it requires in a single meal therefore you can be fed once a day. Some (especially those that feed on left-over table food) feed 2-3 times a day.

choiceText: My bitch is pregnant and getting to her late gestation. Should the frequency of feeding be the same as before?
answerText: Smaller portions of more frequent but rich meals may be better. At late gestation the uterus occupies space and may not allow for bulk feeding.

choiceText: My bitch was mated a month ago. Can I supplement her feed with vitamins and minerals to avoid disorder?
answerText: Once the diet is balanced supplementation with vitamins or minerals is not required

choiceText: Should I increase the quantity of food for my pregnant bitch?
answerText: It depends on the stage of pregnancy. If she is in her early stage of pregnancy, it may not be necessary! You may only increase the quantity at the second half of gestation as increasing at early pregnancy may lead to obesity.

choiceText: My bitch is pregnant and close to delivery and is not eating as before; what should I do?
answerText: Usually at late pregnancy most bitches would have reduced appetite. You can give her normal ration of smaller portions  at a time.

choiceText: What time of the day is best to feed my dog?
answerText: Morning time is usually better over late morning or afternoon and never late evenings. Most importantly, whatever the timing, keep at it and be consistent.

choiceText: When do I start supplementary feeding for my puppies?
answerText: If milk supply is not adequate and there are many litters, supplementary feeding can commence from 3 weeks. Most puppies begin taking semi-solid or solid food from 3-4 weeks.

choiceText: Vaccination
Routine practices
I want to keep exotic dogs but not sure the one appropriate for security purposes
answerText: There are many of such dogs but those that are common and good for security purposes are: German shepherd, Caucasian and Rottweiler

choiceText: Diseases
For some days now my dog has been scratching its body. I observed partial loss of hair and do not know what to do?
answerText: Presence of some parasites (mites, lice) on the body can cause itching and make an animal to scratch its body leading to loss of hair. Sometimes it could be due to infection caused by bacteria. Also when your dog reacts or is allergic to some materials it may cause itching and loss of hair. Consult with your vet doctor for treatment

choiceText: I usually see small raised areas on the body of my dogs and when pressed worms pop out; what causes it?
answerText: This is caused by larva of some flies. If the place where your dog lives is always dirty (the feces and urine) it attracts flies and the flies lay worms that enter the skin of the dog. Always keep the place where your dog stay clean.

choiceText: Marketing
Rabbits
Housing
What type of housing/what should I consider when providing house for my rabbits?
answerText: Ensure the house protects them from rain, wind and sun. It should be strong enough to give protection against predators. In hot areas, build a frame and cover with wire netting; 2.5cm mesh wire netting can be used for the top and sides while 1-1.5cm wire mesh can be used for the floor. The floor can be of timber but holes must be drilled to provide for drainage. Provide some shade using a thatched roof shelter on poles. On cooler areas make a hutch of timber for sleeping area and a wire mesh outside run

choiceText: Should I put my buck in the doe’s hutch now that she is in her season?
answerText: Always put the Doe into the buck’s hutch. Never put the buck into the doe’s hutch as this may upset the buck.

choiceText: Breeding
I want to raise rabbits for sale; how do I select my breeding stock?
answerText: If you know someone doing the business, you may ask him/her to direct you where to get good breeding stock. The stock should be selected from good mothers based on good size and shape and ability to give birth to good litter.

choiceText: My rabbits are 3 months old. I want to know the right age for breeding?
answerText: The right age for breeding rabbits is between 5 and 7 months.

choiceText: I perceive that my female rabbit is pregnant. I want to know how long it takes for her to deliver from conception?
answerText: Pregnancy in rabbits last between 30 and 32 days. Approximately one month from conception.

choiceText: What ratio of male to female rabbits should I keep?
answerText: One buck (male) to a between 8 and 10 does (females)

choiceText: How do I know that my female rabbit is in her breeding season?
answerText: Usually some days to kindling the doe may go off feed. You will notice her to be restless, reproductive organs become swollen, and she will be rubbing against the walls and food containers. She may be throwing herself on one side and trying to contact the rabit in the next pen

choiceText: How many litters should I have per doe per year?
answerText: Allow four litters per doe per year.

choiceText: My doe litters between 8-10 per litter and seems they are too many for her?
answerText: Preferably allow only seven young per litter as more will be too much for the mother.

choiceText: How long should it take before mating my doe after weaning?
answerText: The doe can be mated almost immediately after weaning her young

choiceText: Feed and water
What quantity of water should I provide my rabbits?
answerText: Ensure clean, fresh water is always available.

choiceText: How many times should I feed my rabbits?
answerText: Give them feed twice a day preferably early morning and evening.

choiceText: Vaccination
I learnt that there is a Coccidiosis vaccine in chickens. Can I try it on my rabbits?
answerText: We do not have records of the use of this vaccine in rabbits. Try to take preventive measures for now.

choiceText: Routine practices
What age should I wean my rabbits?
answerText: weaning should be done 8 weeks

choiceText: How do I prepare my doe for kindling?
answerText: Provide very soft hay for lining her nest box. She will usually add her fur that she pulls from her breast area.

choiceText: At what age should I wean my rabbits?
answerText: Rabbits should be weaned at 8 weeks of age.

choiceText: How do I wean my rabbits?
answerText: Remove the doe to another hutch and leave the young rabbits in the old hutch as this will upset them less.

choiceText: What type of feed are good for rabbits?
answerText: Carrots, dried cassava chips, lettuce, cabbage, cowpeas, groundnut vines, green oats, sweet potato vines, turnips and many other grasses

choiceText: Should I give my rabbits only greens and roots?
answerText: Rabbits do moderately well on greens and roots but it will be good to give the concentrates (pellets or meal containing cereals mixed with a protein feed such as cotton-seed cake, groundnut cake or fish meal)

choiceText: Diseases
Recently, 3 out of 10 of my rabbits passed loose stool/diarrhea and have their abdomen swollen/distended; what do I do?
answerText: So many things cause this condition. It may be due to a problem with the feed you gave them recently or they might have coccidiosis or worms. If you started noticing it after a change in feed then it may be their feed. Give drug for coccidiosis and deworm them. Coccidiosis occurs in overcrowded and dirty conditions; ensure clean environment, avoid contaminating feeds and water by rabbit droppings.

choiceText: What type of feed/food may poisonous for my rabbits?
answerText: Do not give them tomatoes or Irish potatoes  vines as these are poisonous to them

choiceText: What should I do when my rabbits are showing signs of sneezing and nasal discharges?
answerText: Your rabbits may be suffering from pneumonia. Antibiotics in water/feed may help in controlling the condition

choiceText: Marketing
What age is an adult rabbit ready for market?
answerText: Rabbits should be ready for the table at four months of age. For the last month increase the grain feed and decrease the green feed. This should give you a good price.
